Real world behavior is the goal. So in

Okay. So part of our our multi-agent
planning approach introduces three kinds
of agents in our solution. The first is
an entity agent. Now this is a type of
agent you're probably most familiar
with. This governs the actions of a
single human, a vehicle, aircraft,
animal, what have you. Right?
Our next type of agent is an entity
unit. So this is logically an agent
who's really just in charge of other
entity level agents, right?
But we have a third type which is an
aggregate unit agent. So he's in charge
of other aggregate agent aggregate unit
agents or other entity unit agents. Now
why would we make this so complicated?
Well, there's a very good reason and
that is that the communication that
happens and that needs to happen between
these types of agents is modeled is
something we can model from the real
world. So in the military domain, the
flow of communication down from a uh
let's say a platoon to its squad to
individual soldiers is a very logical
and very methodical communication
process in the form of orders, commands
and then the flow back in terms of
reports. Right? So we want to not only
model that communication in terms of its
uh the physical communication, the radio
aspects, but also the ability to
separate our agents logically so that at
each at each level an agent
implementation at the entity level
doesn't need to be concerned with the
implementation at the entity unit level
for example.
So on the right hand side you can see
there we have a platoon aggregate unit
agent at the very top
who's controlling three squad level uh

You can do either of those types of

So, let's say for example, we write,
here's the prompt. Write a behavior tree
for a platoon organized into two vehicle
sections and three dismount squads.
The environment is urban and the
temperature is over 100°.
The behavior should include the platoon
moving along a route, dismounting the
troops at a given location, and
performing a search of nearby
structures,
and then neutralizing an enemy.
Once complete, the platoon should

So a portion of that tree might look
something like this. Right? Along the
left hand side, the movement would
evaluate, do I have roads available?
Right? Using that is roads condition. If
so, perform a road march. If not, move

saying move cross country.
But in this case, this is the orders
that are going to be sent to those
vehicle sections to the vehicles to

When they're finished, the tasks here

that'll transition us in sequence over

shift a little bit but I wouldn't

the model that is currently best

prosaic deployment considerations like
the latency uh ease of API usage but one
thing you have to take into account is
most of these large language models were

case of using a large language model to

of game content that's probably not what

instructions or a specialurpose coding
model that's been trained with a higher
percentage of open-source code.
A second consideration is really open
source or closed. Would you rather use
kind of a model that's already the code
has been released, the weights have been
released, you can download it, you can
you can run it on your your own computer
or would you rather use one of the
closed closed models? Typically the
closed models um are the more powerful
powerful models but often come with the
increased pricing. you might get the
better bang for your buck by essentially
going with a smaller open-source model
which you configure for your special use
case.
Of course, there's the question, the
eternal question, how much does size
really matter? So, for our research,
we've used smaller models uh between
kind of two and 8 billion parameters,
but you know, the uh the larger closed
models may have about a trillion
parameters. And I will say this, if you
are interested in multimodal
applications, so combining vision,
language, that kind of thing, you are
going to need a large larger mo model
inherently. If you're more interested in
you utilizing complex prompting, having
the model explain itself, you will
probably do better with the larger
model. For other cases, you might do
fine with a smaller model. The smaller
model will probably help you more in the
pricing department. Typically done by
input output tokens, some some just kind
of by monthly subscriptions. Another
kind of last thing to consider is the
size of the context window because
context is very important. So not really
just the overall number of parameters,
but the amount of input that that model
will support may be the best indicator
of your performance.
So in in our lab typically we are
looking at diverse application cases
that are off a little bit off thebeaten
path that if you're looking at the case
you're trying to do something that does
not match what the model was trained
for. You will probably need to customize
your model with fine-tuning.
And this can be done with the closed
models. uh in some cases the APIs do
support some amount of fine fine-tuning
but often it's best if you use an open
model and then you can delve in into it
and use a variety of these parameter
efficient fine-tuning methods of which
absolutely the most popular two methods
are Laura low rank adaptation which is
what we're using in this project and
quantized Laura. So the key thing about
these models is that they are enormous.
They have a lot of parameters and those
parameters were fitted with data,
enormous data sets. Chances are that you
will be relatively starved of data for
your specialized application. You will
not have very much data. If you don't
have very much data and you're trying to
fit a billion parameters, you're in
trouble because you might have had
10,000 data points, but now you have to
make adjustments to a billion numbers.
You don't really want to do that. So,
what Laura is doing is essentially
saying that we're going to keep and
freeze all these lovely pre-trained
weights, but then we're going to add
these specialized adapters, but we're
going to make these adapters
particularly parameter efficient by
representing them as the product of two
low rank matrices. It keeps the number
of parameters that you're trying to
learn with the training data very small
and enables you to fine-tune for a
specific case. You have the adapters and
as a bonus you can swap them in and out.
If you are care about performance you
can also kind of add the mo add the
adapter directly in to improve the
latency but this essentially is one of
the best ways to customize your model.
Now it may be that you really just don't
have enough data to support fine-tuning.
So then it's all about context, context,
context. Adding context particularly for
coding style tasks is what will help you
the most with probably the most popular
context um addition method is called
retrieval augmented generation. So that
was that's essentially the method that
we've been employing in this project. In
this case, you assume that you have kind
of a small database of documents that
you want to draw into. You create this
this database of the do documents
represent them in a large language
embedding and then when a new query
comes in what you're going to do is
essentially you're going to try to
identify which documents in your data
set are similar to the query and then
those documents get pulled into and
automatically added into the context. So
the generator has that information in
the context when it considers the
outputs and basically between these two
methods Laura and rag that really covers
most of most of what you'll what is
useful. Other kind of fancier methods
like uh contextual activation vectors
and so on may be useful but these two
methods will cover the majority of your
use case.
Now what I'm going to tell you about so

Starcraft 2 players here. Okay. So this

does not actually play a full game of
Starcraft. There is a group out there
that created an LLM that plays Starcraft

that to be not a great project because
of the latencies. So it's really hard to
have your LLM go fast. We can do the
build order in a reasonable time, but to
do all the Starcraft actions is hard. So
in this project, what we do is we use a
large language model that's been
fine-tuned to generate these build
orders, which to some extent you can you
can think of a build order like a plan.
It's telling it's telling you what what
units your Starcraft
um your Starcraft player should be
creating over the next few time steps.
We used a very small LLM, Microsoft's
FI2. It's only 2.8 billion parameters
and it was constructed with a couple of
stages of fine-tuning. one to get the

knowledge and then the second to do
specific build orders. So if you look at
the picture of the model, the snowflake
shows the frozen stuff. The large
language model is just vanilla fi 2 and
then everything marked with a flame is
the trainable section.
So probably the greatest amount of work
in this project was for my PhD student
to go and assemble this text data set of
kind of general Starcraft knowledge. So
what we did is we created this question
answer data set and that's a common
training method. Essentially what you're
doing you get this data set and then
you're training the LLM to be able to
generate answers to these kind of
questions. So our questions are are
specific to Starcraft races
um Starcraft unit types, Starcraft
tactics and so in this data set we
included some example build o orders but
not that many. So this helps us in this
way. So when we prompt the model, what
are the build actions for the Terran
race? If you just ask that question to
the the generic FI2 model, what it would
do is it would show you that it has a
decent knowledge of how real-time
strategy games are played. It
understands that common things would be,
you know, build a barracks, do some
research, build a space station. The
phase one training helps us configure
the model with more specific Starcraft 2
actions. The second part of our
fine-tuning was much more complicated.
We needed a lot of game data. So, we we
found an open- source data set with
replays of 36,000 uh game traces. So,
that's kind of the order of magnitude
that you'd want for this for this sort
of project. And the nice thing about
this data set is it includes win loss
information, includes the actions and it
also in includes essentially the screen
snapshots
because kind of a key problem is how do
we get in all of this rich multimodal
visual information that the players are
looking at? And the way that this is
done is essentially by taking a
multi-layered heat map over the
Starcraft map. So kind of the first
great blob area is just showing kind of
what's the terrain for this snippet of
the board. And then the other things are
different heat maps showing the
placement of different unit types. In
our replay data set, we leverage two
types of features. global features that
have information about resources,
upgrades, techniques, and these kind of
spatial features. Now, at that point, we
didn't have good success with any of the
multimodal models. So, we built our own
kind of custom multimodal adapter using
a vision transformer in Blip 2. And that
essentially enables us to extract
information about what's on the map.
Then essentially what we can do is we
can prompt the MA model in this way.
I have kind of a generic part, but we
can also have this game state part that
has information about the current game
status. And then we're training the
model to output what the next four build
actions should be. And we also look at a
separate macro management task. We try
to have the model predict whether the
whether we're that player is on a
win-loss trajectory. The one thing I
will definitely caution you about this
kind of work is it that we found that at
least for the 52 model is very important
to translate any numeric data into
categorical data. So if you give your
LLM you know that there are seven
buildings you'll get a different
response to then there are a small
number of buildings a large number of
buildings. You also end up finding that
if you use like too much numeric data,
